Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics of Asynchronous Networks, Adaptation and Visualization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will develop the mathematical theories of asynchronous and adaptive networks as part of a general scheme for pattern recognition, visualization of complex dynamics and 'qualitative' computing. The work will combine ideas on adaptive networks inspired by computational neuroscience, notably Spike-Timing Dependent Plasticity (STDP), with mathematical techniques developed in the study of statistical properties of dynamical systems with multiple time scales. We allow for asynchronous dynamics (no global clock); specifically, nodes of the network may not be updated synchronously (at each time step). Of special interest is the further development of a very promising Globally Asynchronous Locally Synchronous (GALS) network architecture that combines randomness (coming from node dynamics) with a loose (sloppy) asynchronous logic. Overall, the research will use mathematical techniques developed in the study of statistical properties of dynamical systems with the mathematics of network dynamics and be guided by numerical simulation and experimentation.

Many physical, electrical and biological systems can be modeled by networks of interacting differential equations and maps. The most realistic models allow for randomness, discontinuity, time delays and asynchrony - there may be no global clock and so the nodes of the network may not be updated synchronously (by way of contrast, the motion of the planets round the sun is synchronous: all the planets continually move and interact, via gravity, with all the other planets). Asynchrony is a characteristic feature of much recent technology as well as of complex biological systems, such as the brain. The project will develop new models for network dynamics that involve a mix of random, asynchronous and deterministic dynamics. As part of the work, it is proposed to refine and develop existing novel visualization tools with the aim of identifying key dynamical features in complex network dynamics, such as patterns of synchronization in large networks. Of great potential significance in applications is the development of new adaptive methods for high speed pattern recognition and learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Award 1265253

 

Project Title

Dynamics of Asynchronous Networks,

Adaptation and Visualization

 

It is now well understood that many problems in technology, engineering and biology can be modelled by networks of interacting subsystems or “nodes”.  Examples range from gene transcription networks (biology), networks of neurons (neuroscience), power grid networks (engineering), neural nets (computer science) and transport and distribution networks. Crucially, many of these networks have a function. For example, transportation networks move people from one point to another, neural networks may perform pattern recognition or computation and power grid networks may be optimizing cost and balancing load and power generation in the context of varying energy supply (wind power and other renewables) and loads. Although small networks may be centrally controlled, large networks typically involve a mix of centralized and decentralized control. Moreover, individual nodes in the network may stop and later restart and the number of nodes and connections in the network may vary over time. These characteristics suggest that classical network models—expressed in terms of a fixed system of differential equations—may not always be applicable. The main achievement of the project was the development of a theory of asynchronous networks that takes account of both network function and the inherently discontinuous character of many of the networks encountered in contemporary science and engineering. The main theoretical result obtained showed that network function can be expressed in terms of the network function of constituent sub-networks. Results of this type are often difficult or impossible to obtain if the focus is on dynamics rather than function.

 

The project research has naturally led to range of conclusions and questions all with potentially significant applications. In particular, we mention the idea of a dynamical deadlock—a situation where the network is unable to complete its function (for example, simultaneous arrival at a 4-way stop sign)—and the realization that non-smoothness (switching), adaptivity and control play a central role in network function. Developing out of project research, work is continuing on power grid modelling (focus on micro-grids), adaptive learning in neuroscience (Spike Timing Dependent Plasticity), visualization of complex network dynamics,  and, most recently, artificial neural nets using continuous dynamics and ideas from asynchronous networks.
